questions.question_text_1: In the context of RNNs, what structural feature of LSTMs helps reduce the impact of vanishing gradients?
question_texts: In the context of RNNs, what structural feature of LSTMs helps reduce the impact of vanishing gradients?

options.option_text: Skip connections
Gated mechanisms like forget and input gates
Weight sharing across layers
Use of dropout

questions.question_text_1: As per gradient descent, we should move towards 180 degrees with respect to gradient direction. What will happen if we move between 90 and 180 degrees? Consider the loss function to be convex.
question_texts: As per gradient descent, we should move towards 180 degrees with respect to gradient direction. What will happen if we move between 90 and 180 degrees? Consider the loss function to be convex.

options.option_text: The loss function will increase.
The loss function will decrease, although not to the maximum possible extent.
The loss function will remain the same.
Can’t say. It depends on other parameters of the convex function.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements about the parameter β in RMSProp is correct?
question_texts: Which of the following statements about the parameter β in RMSProp is correct?

options.option_text: A higher value of β means that past gradients retain more influence on themoving average.
A lower value of β means past gradients have a lesser influence on the movingaverage.
A higher value of β means the current gradient will have lesser influence thanpast gradients.
A lower value of β means the current gradient will have higher influence thanpast gradients.
All of these

questions.question_text_1:
Consider a feed-forward neural network containing three inputs and one output. It consists of 50 hidden layers, each with two neurons. The activation function used in all the hidden layers is ReLU, the output layer uses the Sigmoid activation function for binary classification. The network is trained with a binary cross-entropy loss function.  The network architecture is as follows: 
- Input layer: 3 nodes - Hidden layer: 2 nodes each - Output layer: 1 node 
Assume all weights are initialized to 1 and all biases to 0. For an input of [-10, 5, -20], what will be the output of the neural network?
question_texts:
Consider a feed-forward neural network containing three inputs and one output. It consists of 50 hidden layers, each with two neurons. The activation function used in all the hidden layers is ReLU, the output layer uses the Sigmoid activation function for binary classification. The network is trained with a binary cross-entropy loss function.  The network architecture is as follows: 
- Input layer: 3 nodes - Hidden layer: 2 nodes each - Output layer: 1 node 
Assume all weights are initialized to 1 and all biases to 0. For an input of [-10, 5, -20], what will be the output of the neural network?

options.option_text: Insufficient information

questions.question_text_1: In the transformer model, how are self-attention weights calculated for a given token?
question_texts: In the transformer model, how are self-attention weights calculated for a given token?

options.option_text: By passing the token’s embeddings to softmax function.
Using a feedforward neural network applied to the token’s embeddings.
Through a convolutional operation applied to the token’s neighborhood.
As the dot product between the token’s embeddings and those of all othertokens, followed by a softmax operation.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you have a vocabulary of 5,000 unique words and you want to train a CBOW model with a window size of 3 (on each side) and with an embedding dimension of 100. How many parameters (weights) will the embedding layer have?

questions.question_text_1: Assume that your CBOW model outputs a probability distribution over a vocabulary of 20,000 words for a given context. If the correct target word is word number 150, and the model’s predicted probability for this word is 0.2, calculate the cross-entropy loss for this prediction. (use natural log)

questions.question_text_1: In the context of the Transformer model’s encoder-decoder architecture, which of the following statements are accurate?
question_texts: In the context of the Transformer model’s encoder-decoder architecture, which of the following statements are accurate?

options.option_text: The encoder in a Transformer model is responsible for converting the inputsequence into a continuous representation that the decoder can then use to generate the output sequence.
The decoder in a Transformer model only attends to the encoder’s outputwithout any form of self-attention on its own inputs.
Multi-head attention in the encoder allows the model to jointly attend toinformation from different representations at different positions.
The decoder’s self-attention mechanism includes a masking component toprevent attending to future positions, ensuring the model generates outputs one step at a time.

questions.question_text_1:
Consider a Transformer model with the following specifications for the decoder part:  
• Input dimension (embedding size): 16 • Number of heads in multi-head attention: 2 • Head output dimension: 8 • Dimension of the feed-forward network: 32 • Number of layers in the decoder: 2 Note: The final output from the attention heads is obtained by concatenating the outputs from the individual heads and hence does not cost any additional parameters.
Assume that each decoder layer contains: • One multi-head attention mechanism for self-attention. • One multi-head attention mechanism for encoder-decoder attention. • One feed-forward network. • No bias terms are included. 
Calculate the total number of parameters in the decoder part.
question_texts:
Consider a Transformer model with the following specifications for the decoder part:  
• Input dimension (embedding size): 16 • Number of heads in multi-head attention: 2 • Head output dimension: 8 • Dimension of the feed-forward network: 32 • Number of layers in the decoder: 2 Note: The final output from the attention heads is obtained by concatenating the outputs from the individual heads and hence does not cost any additional parameters.
Assume that each decoder layer contains: • One multi-head attention mechanism for self-attention. • One multi-head attention mechanism for encoder-decoder attention. • One feed-forward network. • No bias terms are included. 
Calculate the total number of parameters in the decoder part.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Deep Learning (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Foundations of Neural Networks**
#### **1. McCulloch-Pitts (MP) Neuron & Boolean Functions**
- **MP Neuron**: Binary threshold unit.
  - Output:
    \[
    f(x) =
    \begin{cases}
    1, & \text{if } \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \geq \theta \\
    0, & \text{otherwise}
    \end{cases}
    \]
  - **AND Function**: Requires all inputs to be `1` → **Threshold (θ) = Number of inputs (5 in Q3)**.

#### **2. Feedforward Neural Networks (FNN)**
- **Architecture**:
  - Input layer → Hidden layers (ReLU activation) → Output layer (Sigmoid for binary classification).
- **Forward Pass Calculation (Q8)**:
  - Given weights initialized to `1` and biases to `0`:
    - ReLU: \( \text{ReLU}(x) = \max(0, x) \).
    - Sigmoid: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
  - For input `[-10, 5, -20]`:
    - Hidden layer output: `ReLU(-10 + 5 + -20) = ReLU(-25) = 0`.
    - Output layer: `Sigmoid(0 * weight + 0 * bias) = 0.5`.

#### **3. Gradient Descent & Optimization**
- **Gradient Descent Update Rule**:
  \[
  \theta_{new} = \theta_{old} - \eta \nabla J(\theta)
  \]
  - **Direction**: Move **180° opposite** to the gradient for minimization.
  - **Angle Impact (Q6)**:
    - **90°–180°**: Loss decreases but **not optimally** (suboptimal step).
    - **0°–90°**: Loss may increase.
- **Optimizers**:
  - **RMSProp**:
    - Exponential moving average of squared gradients:
      \[
      v_t = \beta v_{t-1} + (1 - \beta) g_t^2
      \]
    - **β (Q7)**:
      - High β → More influence from **past gradients**.
      - Low β → More influence from **current gradient**.

---

### **B. Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) & Variants**
#### **1. Vanishing Gradients & LSTMs (Q5)**
- **Problem**: Vanishing gradients in deep RNNs due to repeated multiplication of small gradients.
- **LSTM Solution**:
  - **Gated Mechanisms** (Forget, Input, Output gates) to regulate information flow.
  - **Cell State**: Acts as a "highway" for gradient flow.

#### **2. Sequence-to-Sequence Models (Q9, Q18, Q19)**
- **Encoder-Decoder Architecture**:
  - **Encoder**: Compresses input sequence into a **context vector**.
  - **Decoder**: Generates output sequence from context.
- **Attention Mechanism (Q9)**:
  - Context vector:
    \[
    c_t = \sum_{i=1}^{T} \alpha_{t,i} h_i
    \]
  - **Example Calculation**:
    \[
    c_t = 0.2[1,1,1] + 0.2[0,1,0] + 0.6[0,0,1] = [0.2, 0.4, 0.8]
    \]
- **Parameter Count (Q18, Q19)**:
  - **RNN Parameters**:
    - \( U \) (input → hidden): \( d_{in} \times d_{hidden} \).
    - \( W \) (hidden → hidden): \( d_{hidden} \times d_{hidden} \).
    - \( V \) (hidden → output): \( d_{hidden} \times d_{out} \).
  - **Total Parameters**:
    \[
    \text{Total} = U + W + V + \text{bias terms}
    \]
  - **Example (Q19)**:
    - \( s_t \in \mathbb{R}^2 \), \( \hat{y}_t \in \mathbb{R}^3 \), \( x_t \in \mathbb{R}^6 \).
    - \( U = 6 \times 2 = 12 \), \( W = 2 \times 2 = 4 \), \( V = 2 \times 3 = 6 \).
    - Biases: \( b = 2 \), \( c = 3 \).
    - **Total**: \( 12 + 4 + 6 + 2 + 3 = 27 \) (but answer is 33 → likely includes additional terms).

---

### **C. Attention & Transformer Models (Q10, Q22, Q23)**
#### **1. Self-Attention (Q10)**
- **Calculation**:
  - **Query (Q)**, **Key (K)**, **Value (V)** matrices derived from embeddings.
  - Attention scores:
    \[
    \text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right) V
    \]
  - **Masking in Decoder**: Prevents attending to future tokens (upper-triangular mask).

#### **2. Multi-Head Attention (Q23)**
- **Parameters**:
  - For each head:
    - \( W_Q, W_K, W_V \) (each \( d_{model} \times d_k \)).
  - **Total Parameters**:
    \[
    \text{Total} = 3 \times (\text{num\_heads} \times d_{model} \times d_k)
    \]
  - **Example (Q23)**:
    - \( d_{model} = 16 \), \( \text{num\_heads} = 2 \), \( d_k = 8 \).
    - **Self-Attention**: \( 3 \times (2 \times 16 \times 8) = 768 \).
    - **Encoder-Decoder Attention**: Same as self-attention.
    - **Feedforward**: \( 2 \times (16 \times 32 + 32 \times 16) = 2048 \).
    - **Total per Layer**: \( 768 + 768 + 2048 = 3584 \).
    - **2 Layers**: \( 2 \times 3584 = 7168 \) (but answer is 5120 → likely excludes some terms or uses \( d_{ff} = 16 \)).

#### **3. Transformer Encoder-Decoder (Q22)**
- **Encoder**:
  - Converts input sequence to continuous representation via self-attention.
- **Decoder**:
  - **Masked Self-Attention**: Prevents peeking at future tokens.
  - **Encoder-Decoder Attention**: Attends to encoder outputs.

---

### **D. Word Embeddings & Language Models (Q15, Q16, Q17)**
#### **1. CBOW & Skip-gram (Q15, Q17)**
- **CBOW**:
  - Predicts target word from context.
  - **Parameters**: \( \text{vocab\_size} \times \text{embedding\_dim} \).
  - **Example (Q15)**: \( 5000 \times 100 = 500,000 \).
- **Skip-gram**:
  - Predicts context from target word.
  - **Unique Pairs (Q17)**:
    - For window size `2`, sentence length `n`:
      \[
      \text{Pairs} = n \times (2 \times \text{window\_size})
      \]
    - Example: 10 words → \( 10 \times 4 = 40 \) (but answer is 32 → likely excludes edge cases).

#### **2. Cross-Entropy Loss (Q16)**
- **Formula**:
  \[
  L = -\sum_{i=1}^{V} y_i \log(\hat{y}_i)
  \]
  - For correct class \( y = 1 \), \( \hat{y} = 0.2 \):
    \[
    L = -\log(0.2) \approx 1.609 \ (\text{natural log})
    \]

---

### **E. Regularization & Overfitting (Q14)**
- **Techniques to Prevent Overfitting**:
  - **Data Augmentation**: Artificially expands training data.
  - **Dropout**: Randomly deactivates neurons during training.
  - **Early Stopping**: Halts training when validation loss increases.
  - **Weight Regularization (L1/L2)**: Penalizes large weights.
- **Does NOT Help**: None of the above (all listed techniques help).

---

## **2. Key Equations Summary**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| MP Neuron               | \( f(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & \sum x_i \geq \theta \\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \) |
| Gradient Descent        | \( \theta_{new} = \theta_{old} - \eta \nabla J(\theta) \)                  |
| RMSProp                  | \( v_t = \beta v_{t-1} + (1 - \beta) g_t^2 \)                              |
| Attention               | \( c_t = \sum \alpha_{t,i} h_i \)                                           |
| Self-Attention           | \( \text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right) V \) |
| Cross-Entropy Loss      | \( L = -\sum y_i \log(\hat{y}_i) \)                                          |
| RNN Parameter Count     | \( U = d_{in} \times d_{hidden} \), \( W = d_{hidden}^2 \), \( V = d_{hidden} \times d_{out} \) |

---

## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Neural Network Foundations**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Neural Networks] --> B[MP Neuron]
    A --> C[Feedforward NN]
    A --> D[Gradient Descent]
    B --> B1["Threshold (θ)"]
    B --> B2["Boolean Functions (AND, OR)"]
    C --> C1["ReLU Activation"]
    C --> C2["Sigmoid Output"]
    D --> D1["Learning Rate (η)"]
    D --> D2["Optimizers (RMSProp)"]
```

### **Graph 2: RNNs & Attention**
```mermaid
graph TD
    E[Recurrent Networks] --> F[Vanishing Gradients]
    E --> G[LSTMs]
    E --> H[Sequence-to-Sequence]
    F --> F1["Exploding/Vanishing Gradients"]
    G --> G1["Forget Gate"]
    G --> G2["Input/Output Gates"]
    H --> H1["Encoder-Decoder"]
    H --> H2["Attention Mechanism"]
    H2 --> H2a["Context Vector (c_t)"]
    H2 --> H2b["Softmax over Alignments"]
```

### **Graph 3: Transformers**
```mermaid
graph TD
    I[Transformer] --> J[Self-Attention]
    I --> K[Multi-Head Attention]
    I --> L[Positional Encoding]
    J --> J1["Query, Key, Value"]
    J --> J2["Scaled Dot-Product"]
    K --> K1["Multiple Attention Heads"]
    K --> K2["Concatenation"]
    L --> L1["Sinusoidal Functions"]
```

### **Graph 4: Word Embeddings & Language Models**
```mermaid
graph TD
    M[Word Embeddings] --> N[CBOW]
    M --> O[Skip-gram]
    M --> P[Cross-Entropy Loss]
    N --> N1["Context → Target"]
    O --> O1["Target → Context"]
    P --> P1["Log Probabilities"]
    P --> P2["Negative Sampling"]
```

### **Graph 5: Regularization**
```mermaid
graph TD
    Q[Overfitting] --> R[Dropout]
    Q --> S[Early Stopping]
    Q --> T[Data Augmentation]
    Q --> U[L1/L2 Regularization]
    R --> R1["Random Node Deactivation"]
    S --> S1["Validation Loss Monitoring"]
    T --> T1["Image Augmentation"]
    U --> U1["Weight Penalty"]
```
